Description: A model shield, rectangular and curved, with a raised border. It is decorated with a figure of Harpokrates, wearing Macedonian armour, in high relief. He stands on a small plinth and is dressed in a scale-decorated cuirass over a tunic, with pteryges, and short sleeves; he has a garland round his neck, and is bald with a side-lock. A spear is held in his right hand and a small round shield on his left arm. Pressed into a one-piece mould; at the rear is an applied vertical handle. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt; traces of a white dressing overall. Lower corners damaged.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired in the Fayum. Ptolemaic, second to first century BC. Comparanda: Close, probably from same mould-series: Pingiatoglou 1993: no. 33; Willems and Clarysse 2000: 269, no. 198, perhaps from Memphis: described as being dressed as a Roman general (= Petrie Museum uc8792). Close, but Harpokrates wears a chain-mail cuirass and has a sword and a rectangular shield: Perdrizet 1921: no. 111, from the Fayum, dated Roman period = Sekunda 1995: fig. 95, dated middle of first century BC. Two similar model shields in the Petrie Museum also show this god: uc8793 has a squatting Harpokrates, wearing a tightly woven wreath and a Double Crown, with a rectangular shield and a spear; uc8794 also has a squatting Harpokrates with a large leafy wreath and a Double Crown; he has his finger to his mouth: both are from Memphis. Bibliog. Budge 1925: pl. xxviii.
